item.title: Getting Started with MySQL MCP Server
item.description:
1 Getting Started with MySQL MCP Server Locally

This guide shows you how to set up and use the MySQL Model Context Protocol (MCP) Server on your local machine, focusing on integration with Cursor, an AI-powered code editor.

2 What is MySQL MCP Server?

MySQL MCP Server is a tool that lets AI applications, like Cursor, safely interact with your MySQL database. Instead of writing raw SQL, you can ask questions about your data. The server handles the communication, making database access more structured and secure.

Main github repository is here

item.title: WordPress Command Line Interface a quick guide
item.description:
1 Supercharge Your Local WordPress: A Quick Guide to WP-CLI üíª

WP-CLI (WordPress Command Line Interface) is a powerful tool that lets you manage your WordPress site directly from your terminal. It’s much faster than clicking through the admin dashboard! Here‚Äôs how to get it set up and start using it on your local machine.

item.title: How to use Chrome MCP: a simple guide
item.description: 1 Introductionmcp-chrome (also called Chrome MCP Server) is a Chrome extension‚Äìbased MCP (Model Context Protocol) server. It lets MCP clients (e.g. AI agents, chatbots) connect to your regular Chrome/Chromium browser, use your existing login state, and control or inspect web pages. Main GitHub Repo is here 2 Main Features Works with your real browser (no separate headless instance) Fully local (no remote server) Uses streamable HTTP as connection method (or stdio alternative) Semantic search across tabs (vector index) & content analysis Over 20 ‚Äútools‚Äù (APIs) to interact with browser: navigation, network, screenshots, DOM, bookmarks, history, etc.

item.title: How to use pnpm: a simple guide
item.description:
1 What is pnpm?

pnpm is a package manager for JavaScript. It is like npm or yarn, but it is faster and uses less disk space.

Why?

  • pnpm saves only one copy of each version of a package.
  • Many projects can share the same files.
  • This makes your computer cleaner and faster.

item.title: Python Decorators: A Simple Guide
item.description:
Python Decorators: A Simple Guide

1 What is a Decorator?

A decorator in Python is a function that modifies the behavior of another function. It adds extra functionality without changing the original function code.

2 Why Use Decorators?

Decorators help you:

  • Reuse code
  • Keep functions clean
  • Add logging, timing, or access control
  • Make your code more readable

item.title: How to Properly Catch and Raise Exceptions
item.description: üêç How to Properly Catch and Raise Exceptions ‚Äì A Guide for Junior Developers(This article was created by Qwen AI) Handling exceptions correctly isn’t just about preventing crashes ‚Äî it makes your code more stable, easier to debug, and simpler to maintain. Here are simple, practical rules every junior developer should follow. 1 ‚úÖ Only catch an exception when you know what to do ‚ùå Don’t catch an exception just “because you can”.

item.title: How to Manage Software with Flatpak on Ubuntu 22.04
item.description:
Introduction to Flatpak on Ubuntu 24.04

Flatpak is a system for running applications on Linux in a secure and isolated way. It works on many Linux distributions, including Ubuntu 24.04. Flatpak makes it easy to install apps without worrying about missing dependencies. It also allows apps to be updated easily.

item.title: Parallel Processing In Python3
item.description:
1 ü§î Why Use Parallel Processing?

When running üêç Python programs, some tasks take a long ‚è≥ time to complete. For example, calling an external üåê API or reading large üìÇ files. If we run these tasks one by one, it can be üêå slow. Instead, we can run them in parallel to save ‚è±Ô∏è time.

item.title: Python's **kwargs: What is it?
item.description:
1 Python’s **kwargs: What is it?

In Python, **kwargs is a special syntax that allows you to pass a variable number of keyword arguments to a function.

item.title: Virtual environment in Python 3
item.description:
1 What is a virtual environment?

A virtual environment is a separate Python environment. It is isolated from your system’s Python environment. It lets you install Python packages and libraries. These packages don’t affect other projects or your system’s Python.
